Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Bug Fix] Packages with empty descriptions cause HTTP 500 on reflows" (#9001) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4218

Packages with empty descriptions (empty string), when reflowed, see their description parsed as `null`, which triggers an HTTP 500 on the Package Details page.

_NOTE:_ New packages cannot be uploaded with empty descriptions, these packages were already in the system, probably from before these validation checks were enabled.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Bug Fix] Packages with empty descriptions cause HTTP 500 on reflows" (#9001) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4218

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Using nuget.core 2.14.0 with https://www.nuget.org/api/v2 no longer allows finding packages." (#9000) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

We are using NuGet.Core 2.14.0 with https://www.nuget.org/api/v2 and yesterday we started experiencing an error blocking finding packages.

We are getting the following exception on almost all packages we try to find using FindPackages(...)
System.InvalidOperationException: Response version '3.0' is not supported. The only supported versions are: '1.0', '2.0'.

We are in the process of updating to a newer version of nuget it would be nice to get this fixed.

### Repro Steps

You can also reporduce this manually by for example doing doing a manual request in browser:

1. https://packages.nuget.org/api/v2/FindPackagesById()?id=Newtonsoft.Json
2. Check Response Headers.
3. DataServiceVersion: 3.0 is returned.

### Expected Behavior

Expected behaviour would be to return a version of DataServices that still works with NuGet.Core 2 when using v2 feed.

### Screenshots

Problem when using NuGet.Core
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6636662/153552470-e9d14f01-efdd-4a9c-a17a-4d3ef2f38424.png)

Manual repro:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6636662/153556272-29be80a1-213d-4757-ad40-ddd73843c663.png)


### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Download counters not updating for pre-release packages?" (#8979) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

## TL/DR

It seems to me that the download counter is not working for versions of packages that are marked as pre-release.

The total download for a package that has pre-release versions but also "normal" versions seems to work fine, even though each pre-release version is stuck at 0 (zero).

Please note that the usual delay of 24/48h for the stats to be updated is already passed, since we are at around 6 days.
Also, in these 6 days the other downloads seem to have been updated just fine: I'm talking about my **global** downloads, the downloads for each **package as a whole**, and the downloads for each **package version** that is NOT a pre-release version.


## The setup

Up until last week I had 3 packages on nuget.org , all of them had some versions released in the last year, and none of those versions were pre-release (per semantic versioning).

All was fine.

Last week (Jan 27th to be precise) I uploaded 2 completely new packages (both with a pre-release version) and 3 new versions (again, all pre-release) of the 3 existing packages.
So all of these were in "alpha1" version.
Then about 3 days after that i pushed another pre-release version ("alpha2") for all of the 5 packages.

You can see all 5 of them [here](https://www.nuget.org/profiles/jodydonetti) (screenshot taken 2022-02-02):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1010086/152252639-1d57cb56-60c9-4d44-8e71-c5548df49e88.png)

(Now don't be fooled by the 0.1.9 you can see as the "Latest version" for the first 3 packages, since what is shown is the latest non-pre-release version, as I'm sure you know)

So, all these packages have an actual last version that is pre-release (currently "alpha2").


## The Problem

The problem is that since then, the download counters for each pre-releae version remained stuck at 0 (zero), even though me and other people already downloaded them.

See screenshots below for some evidence.

### Repro Steps

Hypothetically:
- upload a new pre-release version of an existing package OR upload a completely new package (with a pre-release version)
- make some downloads
- wait a couple of days
- download stats will not increase

### Expected Behavior

Download stats SHOULD increase.

### Screenshots

## New package

Downloads for one of the new packages ([this](https://www.nuget.org/packages/ZiggyCreatures.FusionCache.Backplane.StackExchangeRedis/0.1.0-alpha2)) after 6 days:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1010086/152254941-84a73ae1-4146-495c-8c6a-8de0828ef696.png)

## Existing package

Downloads for one of the existing packages ([this](https://www.nuget.org/packages/ZiggyCreatures.FusionCache/0.1.9)) after 6 days:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1010086/152255046-23f4fcda-e4cc-4c13-957e-a64710c3129f.png)

Note that as, I said above, in the last 6 days the downloads for the v0.1.9 kept increasing.

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Feature]: Enhance the NuGetGallery backfill tools to allow a specific set of packages to be reprocessed" (#8961) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

Current the backfill tool only allows the full DB to be reprocess via a "collect" command then an "update" command.


### The Elevator Pitch

Let's add a way to provide a big list of package IDs and versions to reprocess. These IDs and versions can be sourced from NuGet.Insights or Gallery DB depending on the situation. 

### Additional Context and Details

It looks like we may have some data issues in the package compatible frameworks data. This will allow us to fix bugs and reprocess select packages which is much faster than a full backfill.

Events.RelatedBody:
The current syntax is powerful, but also may allow you to get yourself in a fragile state with duplicate etc. 

This is a task to validate things such as prefix reservations etc.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: NuGet tooling to view package prefix reservation" (#11594) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console, MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

With package source mapping, you can establish a 1-N relationship between a package identity and a source. 
When using package prefix patterns, you may want to consider things like, is this prefix reserved on nuget.org, and use that as a means to make a decision. 

For example, one would want to know given a package id, where it's prefix is reserved, or if so, which one. 

Note that there might not be easy ways to get this data from the servers, so this might span client + server.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add `--all` option for dotnet list package" (#11551) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently customer have to make 2 separate queries to find out both `outdated` and `vulnerable` packages with `dotnet list package`, instead we need `--all` which shows all deprecated, vulnerable, and outdated top level and transitive packages

https://github.com/NuGet/Home/pull/11446#discussion_r766860629

I'm including screenshot given GH is not good at tracking comments/discussion.
![image.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5eb1d84a3cd56675c3efe510/b416b4ff-8189-424a-8aec-e315e8aad49b)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Responsiveness] RestoreOperationLogger blocking large number of thread pool threads trying to get access to the output window pane" (#11501) at NuGet/Home
Reopened issue "Generate nuget.config file from NuGet CLI" (#9539) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): `NuGet.exe`

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): `5.5.1.6542`

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): `3.1.201`

VS version (if appropriate): `Visual Studio 2019`

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): `Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.18363.778]`

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: `No.`

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

`N/A`

## Other suggested things

In `npm`, there is a `npm init -y` command that can generate a default `package.json` file.

In `tsc` (TypeScript), there is a `tsc --init` command that can generate a default `tsconfig.json` file.

I think `nuget` (NuGet CLI) should have something like that to generate a default `nuget.config` file.

I know .NET Core CLI have something like this: `dotnet new nugetconfig`. But there is no equivalent CLI argument to generate a default `nuget.config` file just like .NET Core did.

### Verbose Logs

Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)

`N/A`

### Sample Project

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!

`N/A`

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: NuGet.Client TopologicalSortUtility Retrieves Dependencies From Wrong Location" (#11513) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet SDK

### Product Version

NuGet.ProjectModel 6.0.0

### Worked before?

don't know

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

- NuGet.ProjectModel.DependencyGraphSpec provides static method SortPackagesByDependencyOrder
- this in turn uses NuGet.Packaging.TopologicalSortUtility
- method CalculateRelationships retrieves a package's dependencies via PackageInfo.Package.Dependencies (line 69)
- but these top-level dependencies are always empty, since dependencies are located at each target framework
- see, e.g., [https://www.jerriepelser.com/blog/analyze-dotnet-project-dependencies-part-1/](url)
- so, instead, dependencies should be collected from each target framework (see link)
- the current behaviour leads the topolocial sort utility to believe that no package has any dependencies at all, resulting in a complete arbitrary package order (which is not sorted by dependency order at all)

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

In `npm`, there is a `npm init -y` command that can generate a default `package.json` file.

In `tsc` (TypeScript), there is a `tsc --init` command that can generate a default `tsconfig.json` file.

I think `nuget` (NuGet CLI) should have something like that to generate a default `nuget.config` file.

I know .NET Core CLI have something like this: `dotnet new nugetconfig`. But there is no equivalent CLI argument to generate a default `nuget.config` file just like .NET Core did.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: msbuild 17 restores packages.config nugets into different folder than msbuild 16" (#11593) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

msbuild 17.0.0.52104

### Worked before?

msbuild 16.11

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

I have a .NET 4.6.1 WPF project with packages.config referencing one old nuget DevExpress.Xpf.PivotGrid 14.2.3.
This nuget has a bug(?) in the nuspec file - it has <version>14.2.3.0</version> there, see that zero at the end.

When I used 'nuget restore oursln' with VS2019/msbuild 16 installed, this package got restored into 
**packages/DevExpress.Xpf.PivotGrid.14.2.3**

but after installing VS2022/msbuild 17, it's restored into folder
**packages/DevExpress.Xpf.PivotGrid.14.2.3.0**

This effectively breaks our solution, it cannot be built with VS2022, because with packages.config all dll paths from nuget packages are explicit in the csproj including the /packages/DevExpress.Xpf.PivotGrid.14.2.3 path.

I guess this can be solved by switching to PackageReference or SDK style project, but it should be fixed in my opinion to match the behavior of VS2019/msbuild 16.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Allow PackageSourceMapper to report sources that are unused add configure the minimal set" (#11592) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved Other/NA ### The Elevator Pitch I used the PackageSourceMapper tool on NuGet/Insights. Unknown to me, several of my feeds were not even needed anymore. It would be cool if PackageSourceMapper detected these cases and include the minimal set of `` entries that are needed. I did get one hint, like this: 
Start creating recommendation nugetPackageSourceMapping.config file.
    - NuGet.org packageSource key matching 523 packages created.
    - nuget-build package source didn't match any packages.
    - dotnet-tools packageSource key matching 10 packages created.
    - azure-sdk-for-net packageSource key matching 13 packages created.
    - NuGetPackageExplorer packageSource key matching 2 packages created.
But in this case my "azure-sdk-for-net" source had all of its packages also on NuGet.org and could therefore be removed. Ideally it would report that `azure-sdk-for-net` could be removed since the packages fetched from that feed are the same as those fetched from NuGet.org. ### Additional Context and Details _No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: PackageSourceMapper, configure package ID patterns using original casing" (#11591) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Other/NA

### The Elevator Pitch

I gave the PackageSourceMapper tool a try on NuGet/Insights and it is awesome! Just have some feedback. When it generates `<package pattern="..." />` XML nodes, would it be possible to use the original casing of package IDs? It would make it more readable and would align with what the tooling does for adding PackageReference (original case is used).

For example, `BuildBundlerMinifier`, `MessagePackAnalyzer`, and `NuGetPackageExplorer` are all a bit harder to read without capitalization.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_
